user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

[Hospital Letterhead]

Date: 2024-03-20

To: [Patient’s Name]
[Patient’s Address]

Dear [Patient’s Name],

This letter serves as the discharge summary for your hospitalization at [Hospital Name] from March 10, 2024, to your expected discharge on March 20, 2024. We are writing to provide an overview of your stay and to outline the follow-up care required after your discharge.

You were admitted to our facility on March 10, 2024, following a fall that resulted in a subsequent loss of consciousness. Upon initial evaluation, a decreased level of consciousness was observed, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 11, and you exhibited slurred speech. A CT scan conducted on March 11, 2024, confirmed the presence of an intracerebral hemorrhage in the right hemisphere, consistent with a hemorrhagic stroke.

During your admission, your continuous care included monitoring for neurological deficits, given your presentation with right-sided weakness and persistent slurred speech. Laboratory investigations revealed a slightly low hemoglobin level and an elevated white blood cell count. The coagulation profile indicated an elevated International Normalized Ratio (INR), suggesting prolonged bleeding time, which was significant in your management plan.

Your treatment regimen included the administration of Mannitol at a dosage of 0.25 g/kg every 6 hours to manage cerebral edema and the introduction of antihypertensive medications to control blood pressure variations as required. Despite these interventions, your neurological status demonstrated limited improvement with ongoing right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and signs of agitation and confusion noted during the evening rounds on March 11, 2024.

Throughout your stay, safety measures were implemented to prevent falls, given the initial incident that led to admission. Regular discussions were held with your family regarding your prognosis and the necessity for continued care.

As of the latest assessment, your condition remains critical, emphasizing the need for close monitoring and continued rehabilitation. Therefore, you are not deemed safe for discharge at present, and further in-hospital care will be required to address your needs.

Upon stabilization, it is anticipated that your post-discharge plan will include referrals to a neurologist and a rehabilitation specialist to support your recovery. Detailed instructions regarding medication and therapeutic interventions will be provided at the time of discharge.

Please do not hesitate to contact [Contact Information] should you require any clarification or support post-discharge.

We wish you all the best for your recovery.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___
Resident Physician
[Hospital Name]
[Contact Information]
